Gemini: To try and isolate the problem, let's simplify your app.py to a minimal "Hello, World!" Flask application. This will help us determine if the issue is with Flask itself in the Docker environment, or something specific to your original app.py code.

Please MODIFY your app.py in C:\AI-Execution-System\deployment\terraform\ to be EXACTLY this minimal Flask app:

from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/')
def hello_world():
    return 'Hello, World from Flask!'

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True, host='0.0.0.0', port=8080)
Make sure your app.py file in C:\AI-Execution-System\deployment\terraform\ contains ONLY this code and nothing else.

After modifying app.py to this minimal Flask app, run universal-deploy-script.sh AGAIN:

./universal-deploy-script.sh --project ai-execution-system --region us-central1 --type run
Let's see if this minimal Flask app deploys and runs successfully in Cloud Run. If even this simple app fails with ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'flask', it would strongly indicate a more fundamental problem with the Docker image or Cloud Run environment itself, despite the successful pip install.

If this minimal app does work, then the issue is likely somewhere in your original app.py code, even though the error message is still misleadingly pointing to flask.

Please modify app.py to this minimal Flask app, re-deploy, and let me know if it works or if you still get the ModuleNotFoundError error.

Let's try this minimal app to narrow down the problem! LFG!
